intro: Dendrophthora turrialbae, commonly known as the Turrialba ghost fungus, is a basidiomycete fungus belonging to the family Tricholomataceae. It is a saprophytic organism that decomposes dead wood, playing a crucial role in nutrient cycling within forest ecosystems. The fungus is characterized by its delicate, translucent fruiting bodies that often appear as ghostly shapes on decaying tree trunks. It is primarily found in tropical and subtropical regions, particularly in Central and South America. Due to its ecological significance and unique morphology, it is of interest to mycologists and conservationists alike.
